title-group.article-title: A unique presentation of varicella-zoster neuropathy with a thoracolumbar rash and acute urinary retention

author-notes.corresp: Neil Ryan, ENT Department, Southwell Street, Bristol BS2 8EG, UK. Email: neilryan@nhs.net

abstract.p: A 47-year-old female presented to a tertiary centre with a rare case of acute urinary retention (AUR) with a concomitant vesicular rash over the thoracic region that was clinically consistent with unilateral herpes zoster reactivation.
Diagnosis was made by clinical examination. She was managed conservatively and discharged with oral aciclovir.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a rare cause of the commonly diagnosed condition of acute urinary retention (AUR).1 Its pathophysiology is attributed to impairment of the detrusor reflex. Clinical diagnosis is established by identification of the pathognomonic unilateral vesicular skin eruption in a dermatomal distribution. Published cases of VZV-associated AUR report sacral herpetiform rashes.
Here, we present a noteworthy case of AUR with an associated thoracolumbar rash, as opposed to the typical sacral distribution.

sec.title: The case
sec.p: A 47-year-old female presented to a tertiary referral centre after a failed trial-without-catheter. Her initial presentation to general practice had been with a four-day history of suprapubic discomfort and hesitancy. Five days later, she presented to a minor injuries unit and was catheterised (residual volume: 1500 ml). She returned to her general practitioner, to whom she reported bilateral lower limb paraesthesia and decreased sensation in a saddle distribution. She had not defecated for seven days by the time she was admitted to tertiary care. Further examination yielded a vesicular rash on her posterior thorax consistent with active VZV. Her past medical history had included three episodes of active VZV infection.

She was treated with intravenous aciclovir and laxatives. On day nine, she successfully passed urine following removal of the catheter and was discharged home on the proceeding day with three days’ oral aciclovir remaining. She had no further complaints.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Urinary microscopy and culture were negative. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the lumbosacral spine and abdominal ultrasound scan (USS) were unremarkable. Lumbar puncture (LP) was normal. The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was negative for cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, herpes simplex virus and VZV. The sample was not oligoclonal. Routine bloods tests were normal.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Fewer than 150 cases of VZV-associated AUR have been reported worldwide. None, to the best of our knowledge, report thoracolumbar vesicles. The stereotyped distribution is sacral.

Primary infection is followed by a latency in which VZV colonises the dorsal root ganglia.2 Cutaneous reactivation is manifest as an erythematous vesicular macropapular rash, which is present unilaterally in at least one dermatome.3 Sensory changes such as marked allodynia often follow its resolution (postherpetic neuralgia).

Occasionally in immunocompetent patients, and especially in immunocompromised patients, VZV can spread to the brain and spinal cord.2 In immunocompromised hosts, the resulting myelitis or encephalitis is more protracted.

Three syndromes of VZV-associated bladder dysfunction are known:4,5 zoster retention (presented here), zoster cystitis and zoster myelitis. All three are attributable to myelitis of sacral nerve roots 2 and 3.6 As in this case, retention commonly presents alongside constipation due to anal sphincter dysfunction.5

It should be noted that our cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) PCR was negative for VZV. A positive result is required for the diagnosis of VZV only in the absence of rash (Zoster sine herpete). Patients with VZV infection who exhibit dermatomal rashes and concomitant radiculitis have been shown to demonstrate positive CSF PCR for VZV in only 43% of cases.7 The mean duration between the onset of vesicular rash and LP was 6.1 days in this study. The authors demonstrated a positive PCR in 61.5% of samples harvested within seven days of rash onset, compared with just 25% of samples collected after seven days. It is therefore unsurprising that our CSF PCR was negative for VZV at 12 days after initial presentation.

Our management was conservative, as supported by both the literature1,6 and our results. After full and normal investigations, clinicians should aim to make a diagnosis on clinical grounds utilising the pathognomonic rash, irrespective of a negative PCR result. Treatment should include catheterisation, therapeutic-dose aciclovir and follow-up urodynamic studies. Prognosis is excellent, with recovery expected within 10 weeks of presentation.3

We use this case to highlight the clinical nature of the diagnosis, based on a thorough history of VZV, a herpetiform rash (not limited to the lumbosacral region) and without the need for a positive PCR result.
